column9: People say they can't see anything. But there's a flashlight in the game, so you can see everything. The game is designed in an unusual way. I never figured out where the end was, so I played it through twice. On the gameplay side, I'd like to point out the pretty good sauna design. The sounds constantly remind you to play for less than two hours or you won't get your money back. I still don't understand the plot. We're locked in a barn. We escape, rob a house, a gas station, and steal a car. There's a meaningful message, as opposed to just the sense of fear. It's hard to pass up this masterpiece of American game development. I give it 7 out of 10. (Reminded me of PT)

While this game's visuals are pretty nice, $5 to me is kind of pushing it. There's not a lot of substance to the game and *spoiler* there's no real threat the entire time. The ambiance is pretty good as I was on edge a bit with the creaking windmill and such, despite being pretty sure there was no real threat. The ambiance and approaching sounds in the woods when you attempt to escape where pretty good too.

Towards the beginning, the lights go out and the doorbell rings. At this time, while you can still find your way to the door, it's very difficult to see and from a game playing perspective near total darkness in a game where you have to actually feel your way around is not fun, it's just annoying. I also felt like some mechanics weren't really explained, such as starting up the car and in a much smaller case, opening the shake's door. Both require multiple tries, with the car being a lot more unpredictable as far as how long you have to hold the button, or how many times you have to press it.

All in all, I do appreciate the effort that that creator(s) put into making a game. Like I said, good ambiance and graphics. The controls were a bit off, some minor details weren't very clear, the game didn't really have an actual end, and that scene at the beginning was waaay too dark. Honestly, if the game didn't loop (or if it had and ending to be more clear that I missed it) and it had an actual resolution and the scene at the beginning wasn't so pitch black, I could be a bit more iffy. Hope you create more stuff, stay on it because you've got a start to something, but it just needs a little more of a push.

"At Home" is a first-person horror game.

We're ambushed by a few strangers and put in a small hideout. When we wake up, we manage to open the door, but we can't escape from the property, which contains a normal-sized house, a barn, and a small gas station. This is actually only due to the invisible walls that have been built around the area. If we were to be realistic, we'd just have to start walking...

But apart from that, the game is also a complete joke, because it's the same game as "Polterheist." And not just in principle, it's exactly the same game. We're on the exact same property with the same house, with the same cars parked in front of it, and the same barn. Everything is exactly the same. Even the sounds are the same. Only the crappy, dysfunctional gameplay has a slightly different focus. So, we also have to find keys and stuff, just somehow differently. Like, kind of like that. And at least we don't have to break in.

Otherwise, nothing in this asset set collection works. It's funny that we can just push one of the cars parked in front of the house in front of us. Superpowers.

Even if it weren't a copy of "Polterheist," the game would be zero fun anyway. The gameplay is horrible, the atmosphere is stupid, mechanically almost nothing works, and you're constantly wondering why you have to be bothered with this data garbage.

The game can best be summed up by the back entrance of the house. If you open this door, there's a tiny, completely empty room measuring two meters by two meters. No door, nothing. There, but completely pointless. And that's exactly what the whole game is like.

Rating:
3/10 Atmosphere
1/10 Story
4/10 Graphics
6/10 Sound
1/10 Gameplay
0/10 Balancing
0/10 Fun

Conclusion:
1 to 1 copy of "Polterheist."

1/10 Overall Rating

There's hardly any reason for a serious review, so here's what happens in At Home. During your first few seconds of the game, you'll be stopped at 1 second intervals to be fed a haphazard tutorial. The lights will go out and you'll be stuck, wandering aimlessly in the pitch-dark for a phone. You've seen a phone, so you try to pick it up to no avail. You wander around more, maybe find a door that opens to the outside and you step through it. You then wake up in a shack that you have to stumble out of. You'll find a flashlight and, eventually, a key amid the primarily empty rooms of the house you were just in. You'll try to use the key everywhere, including a barn and a gas station, until you realize that you need to use it in a vehicle. The vehicle does nothing... unless you keep holding the W key and then it will eventually go.

What do you do then? Do you drive away from this abominable shack? Of course not. The truck drops you off in the middle of a road, presumably having broke down, and you run in a straight line for the next 2 minutes until you wind up back at... you guessed it... the same house. You find a key, go into the house and find another key, go back to the gas station to get, le gasp, a crowbar, so that you can go get the key to the same truck that broke down which is now somehow back at the house, and you get in the truck and drive away. Game over, you start again from the beginning. Freaking BRILLIANT.

You'll do all of this garbage while using a flashlight that only points to the right 1/3rd of your screen; making the other 2/3rds completely useless. Let this be a lesson to you folks, always check and double check the developer and publisher of a game. If I had noticed that At Home was made by the same dingleberry that made Polterheist I would've never wasted a buck. The best thing about this game is that the store page (and in-game tutorial) says that you have to be quiet and stealthy to avoid being detected by cameras. Spoiler alert, there are no cameras. One of the biggest crocks of crap on Steam, neigh unrivaled.

[quote=][u]At Home[/u] is a game with failed potential. In At Home, strangers come into your house and kidnap you. You then must escape from the locked hut you find yourself in. The description can continue, but as another reviewer put it, â€œ[a] lot of words [in the description,] but not all true.â€ The story is poorly written, there is no fear of dying because you never see the kidnappers, there is no need for stealth, the game is plagued with bugs, and questionable technical decisions run amok.

Where is the storyline? In At Home, there are no journal notes, no dialogue, and no other information that offers any insight into the story. We never see the kidnappers and the game has no real ending â€“ it just loops to the beginning. A big point of contention for me and other players is the power outage event during the introduction. Here, we must echolocate a phone ring in a pitch-black apartment. It is frustrating because you can literally see nothing, movement seems clunky, and we had no prior opportunity to scan the layout. 

The element of â€˜stealthâ€™ should be excluded from the gameâ€™s description. At Home advises us to be careful of where we hide because the kidnappers have placed CCTV cameras around the house. But until those CCTV  are actually implemented, we will remain free to run around and explore without fear of dying. In addition, if you were to die, or say, take a break, then you would have to start over from the beginning because there are no save points.

[u]At Home[/u] has the potential to become a good Stealth game. But developer [u]BisquitPlay[/u] has to become more involved with the community for that to happen. They released At Home on March 27, 2019 and already by May of the same year it was discounted at 90% of the original price. That is not a good indicator. He should address at least some of the negative reviews, answer discussion posts, try to add Steam Achievements, and carry out an update schedule.[/quote]

Where is the storyline? In At Home, there are no journal notes, no dialogue, and no other information that offers any insight into the story. We never see the kidnappers and the game has no real ending â€“ it just loops to the beginning. A big point of contention for me and other players is the power outage event during the introduction. Here, we must echolocate a phone ring in a pitch-black apartment. It is frustrating because you can literally see nothing, movement seems clunky, and we had no prior opportunity to scan the layout. 

The element of â€˜stealthâ€™ should be excluded from the gameâ€™s description. At Home advises us to be careful of where we hide because the kidnappers have placed CCTV cameras around the house. But until those CCTV  are actually implemented, we will remain free to run around and explore without fear of dying. In addition, if you were to die, or say, take a break, then you would have to start over from the beginning because there are no save points.

[u]At Home[/u] has the potential to become a good Stealth game. But developer [u]BisquitPlay[/u] has to become more involved with the community for that to happen. They released At Home on March 27, 2019 and already by May of the same year it was discounted at 90% of the original price. That is not a good indicator. He should address at least some of the negative reviews, answer discussion posts, try to add Steam Achievements, and carry out an update schedule.[/quote]

At Home is a game in the "What should I do? Where should I go?" genre, very popular among indie developers, with a hint of horror.

The plot, in a nutshell: you're sitting at home, and suddenly someone UNEXPECTEDLY turns off the power! SUDDENLY, the phone rings!! You try to find the source of the sound, but all you find is trouble: YOU'VE BEEN KIDNAPPED!!!

Later, we find ourselves in a barn with a door that opens after "N" keystrokes. After escaping, we find ourselves in a small location with a house, a completely empty barn, a gas station, and a couple of cars.

Having found a flashlight, thoughtfully illuminated by the developer, which only illuminates the RIGHT side of the screen instead of the center, and after exploring the house and the car key (!), we're allowed to drive it a full TWO METERS, after which the loading magic takes us to a dead end, from where we, now without a flashlight (!), must run through the forest until we get hit again with a blunt object.

And then "Groundhog Day" begins, which I honestly couldn't complete on my own, and attempts to find those who could were unsuccessful.

The player must complete the same actions, but now you'll be hindered by locked doors, for which you'll have to find keys or simply enter through a window. Or rather, THROUGH a window. More attempts to leave, some cutscenes with a car driving towards us, and then everything seems to repeat itself. Or maybe the game has already ended and started over. I don't know. No one knows.
That seems to be where all the content ends.

[h1]CONCLUSION[/h1]
This "horror" isn't scary at all, there's no plot, and the gameplay is irritating rather than engaging. There are no cards or achievements either. I don't recommend buying THIS.

column8:
I don't even know what this is. Within the first 20 seconds of the game, you are thrown into darkness, but the graphics are awful. Just a bunch of weird dark shapes that resemble very little. You spend your time smashing the E key hoping to find SOMETHING! You hear a constant ringing sound. I have gone close to this sound many times and no matter what, i cannot seem to interact with anything at all to switch it off. It would be nice to see at least SOME THING!!! I might as well have my monitor switched off at this rate. 

If they want this game to succeed, then for pete's sake, don't put a person into pitch black and make movement very difficult. I can hear clicking as I open and close doors but I seem to go back and fourth around the same areas. We need some visuals, even if its only 5%-10% to see where on earth we are going and what we are doing. Sheesh! 

Don't waste your money on this game. It sounded good. But due to the extreme darkness of it, I never got to the fun part. If indeed there even was a fun part. Very disappointing indeed.

I've even requested a refund. Yes, it was that awful.

It was a very big mistake of me to buy this game.
in the first 5 minutes I got stuck because they turn off all of the lights at the start FORCING you to wander through pitch darkness until you get clocked in the back of the head,
Then you wake up in a cabin where the only way out is getting bored/frustrated resulting in mashing E on the door until the lock actually breaks.
and then you have to wander another house in PITCH BLACK AGAIN to find a car key,
and even if you manage to find the flashlight near the van its super-awkward to use since its stuck pointing to the far right of your screen.
I dont want to spoil more but I just want to say I was dissapointed that almost ALL of the puzzles could only be solved by getting either frustrated or bored and mashing the E or A key.
I also want my money back
